11:19 am
BE

The MSCI Hotels Restaurants & Leisure index (+6%) outperformed
European markets (+2%) in 2015 despite a sharp de-rating in H2 (-7%).
We see 12% upside to our January-17 Price Targets, and retain an OW
skew in our ratings in line with our strategists’ OW rating on Consumer
Discretionary sectors. But our forecasts of 8.5% CY16e EPS growth imply
that a degree of re-rating will be necessary to achieve this performance.
This prompts us to screen out stocks at relative P/E highs against peers: we
downgrade Merlin to UW, Autogrill to UW, and TUI to N. Elior, SSP,
and WTB are our key OW convictions across two themes: 1. capital about
to be put to work in Catering mid caps, and 2. capex-driven rollout stories
becoming less attractive given high ROCE expectations.

BE

 1. Mid-caps should continue to lead in Catering, put capital to work.
Elior (retain Overweight, Analyst Focus List stock) remains our top pick
in the Leisure sector, still trading at a discounted valuation (16.5x
CY17e P/E vs peers on 18.3x) for some of the strongest potential Total
Shareholder Returns in the space (14.6% over 16e-18e vs peers on
13.7%). Deploying excess cash into M&A would bring 15% further
upside to our FY20e forecasts, based on our analysis (note). SSP (OW,
19.3x P/E for 19.4% TSR) is nearing 1.5x Net Debt / EBITDA (we
expect by Sept-16), which we would see as an efficient level to start
returning excess cash to shareholders (JPMe 4.2% excess FCF yield).

BE

 2. Rollout stories become less attractive, prefer WTB over MERL.
We retain Whitbread at OW. Our rebased estimates leave valuation
upside potential, despite factoring in lower LFL assumptions (FY18e
EPS forecast cut -1.9%) and higher capex (FY18e capex forecast
increased +36%), resulting in flat 15% ROCE over 16e-20e. We see a
CY17e P/E of 14.5x as attractive for 11.0% EPS growth. We downgrade
TUI to N (from OW) and Merlin to UW (from N) on valuation grounds
and see downward bias to our rollout-driven forecasts, our estimates
implying continued ROCE improvements.

11:20 am
BE

One can compress that into an argument for the sector selloff, but not easily.

Whitbread PLC (WTB:LSE): Last: 4,010, down 126 (-3.05%), High: 4,101, Low: 3,992, Volume: 330.05k

11:26 am
BE

Yeah. Perhaps the people who eat at Garfunkels and Frankie & Benny's really are changing their behaviour because of a largely illusory terrorist threat.

BE

It's plausible. Given they eat at Garfunkels and Frankie & Benny's, they already show a poor sense of judgement.

BE

Anyway, for 2016 we get Brexit, wage costs and global slowdown all referenced in the outlook.

11:27 am
BE

Let me put some new forecasts to all this. Here's Stifel.

BE

Like for Like Sales : Increased by 1.5% (up 2% after 45 weeks), with like for
like sales down around 1% in the final seven weeks. Total sales increased by
7.9% (up 8% after 45 weeks). Issues cited for the poor performance include
difficult trading in North (15% of units) and Scotland (12% of units ) due to rain
/ flooding, although the direct impact from flooding of restaurants was
marginal, lower retail footfall particularly in larger retail centers and some
weakness in Central London. While the impact of the Star Wars film was
positive, the main benefit occurred in the first week of 2016 given the year end
of 27 December. Trading in the Airport concessions and Pub Restaurants
were better than for the group as whole.

BE

Operating Margin : We expect the operating margin improved by 20-30 points
for the year, in line or slightly better than expected.
New Openings : Some 44 new restaurants opened in 2015 in line with
guidance. For 2016 management expect a broadly similar number of
restaurant openings. Returns from new restaurants remain strong, with
payback period of under 3 years.
Finance : Cash generation is strong and net debt at December 2015 will be
under £40m. The financial position of the group remains very strong with a net
debt : EBITDA ratio of under 0.5x.

11:27 am
BE

Outlook, Forecasts : Profits in 2015 are expected to be towards the middle of
the current range of market expectations and we are not changing our pre tax
forecast of £87m. While the opening weeks of 2016 have started well,
management is more cautious on the outlook, given the slower than expected
sales performance in Q4. Accordingly we revise our like for like sales
assumption to 1% and reduce our pre tax profit forecast by £2m to £93m.
Valuation : While the trading statement is weaker than expected, we note the
shares have in the past paid too much attention to short term like for like sales
data and our profit revision is limited. The attractions of strong underlying cash
generation (underlying free cash flow yield of 8.4%) and a high return on
capital of 30% remain intact. Our revised price target of 605p is based on
16-17x earnings for 2016. We consider the main risks are a downturn in the
UK economy, increased competition or a significant reduction in airport
passenger numbers

BE

Interesting, perhaps, that business is falling off in Central London etc (where the competition at £20 a head is getting better, I'd argue) but not at airports (where your customers have literally no choice).

BE

So you are (or were) paying 17 times 2016 for a company whose expansion largely depends on people not opening decent restaurants near its own.

11:30 am
PM

ha, yes

BE

And note, restaurant owners are famously bad at considering how they might actually make a profit.

BE

Anyway, that's that.

Christmas was very strong.

Group like-for-like sales grew by 0.4% for the 19 weeks to 9 January 2016 - our first reported increase for over four years.

Four years!

11:33 am
BE

Let me grab Jefferies to summarise.

BE

Trading momentum improved considerably into Christmas, with UK LFL of +1.3% well ahead of JEFe/cons of -1.7%/-2.3%. Today's call confirmed that Tesco was still cycling considerable vouchering activity in Q3 (at a cost of c.100bps to LFL); this headwind was not a feature in the 6 most recent weeks of trade (to 9 Jan). The group also flagged a strong contribution
from .com. and marked non-food accretion to UK sales (given clothing sales at +5% and
seasonal g.m. at +18%). The large Extra stores performed well. It remains to be seen whether this is due to a temporary deflection of footfall away from the high street given weather conditions, or a more permanent shift in customer patterns.

BE

International impressive. The trading update was completed by remarkable
international progress. Asian Q3/Xmas LFL of 3.7%/4.4% implies a stunning recovery
vs. Casino's Thai operations. Similarly, European LFL of 1.5%/2.5% points to continued
progress. In both cases this follows much greater commercial flexibility warranted to the
two regions since the start of fiscal 15/16.
Focus on rights issue risk continues, judging by the Q&A at today's call. The group's
position remains the same, with £3.5bn of Korean proceeds at its disposal to comfortably
face any debt redemptions falling due in the next couple of years. Indeed, the hint was
of significant cashflow headroom being made available in future from working capital
improvements (more with the FY results).

11:34 am
BE

Too early to call the UK turn but the trend that has recently emerged is that of a
sharp improvement in momentum at the quoted grocers (see chart attached). We continue
to model a Tesco UK recovered margin of 2.2% given only 40% freehold. Whilst value
characteristics are emerging here, MRW continues to offer a more attractive FCY on a
considerably less leveraged capital structure.

BE

(@Mouselet: yes, precisely. I've argued all this at length with every restaurateur who's had the misfortune to meet me in the pub, and have never left believing I've changed a single opinion.)

11:42 am
BE

Let me grab some sellside here. Numis floated it, so here's them.

BE

Headline sales growth at B&M remained very robust during Q3. The -0.7% UK LFL
performance was probably better than expected and in our view is understandable
given the mix of sales, market backdrop and conservative definition. The group is
on track for market forecasts for c.17% profit growth in FY16 and we think that it
could sustain double digit growth for many years from the UK alone. Meanwhile, the
recent fall in the share price has narrowed the valuation premium to the sector to
20% (at 18x PE to cal-16F). We reiterate our recent recommendation upgrade to Buy.

BE

● Sustained UK revenue growth: UK sales growth was 24.4%, including LFL at -0.7%.
This was affected by the worsening backdrop in food/ FMCG (according to Kantar), a
c.-2% headwind from new store cannibalisation (Numis estimate), mild weather effect
on seasonal lines and modest impact from service levels following the addition of two
major DC facilities. Trading improved during December, with positive LFL, and we
expect a more normal pattern of trade to have prevailed since then as weather and
Black Friday effects fade. The new space contribution remained robust at +25%. 15
stores were opened during Q3, with a net 62 YTD, on track for 80 for the FY.
● Further encouraging signs from Germany: Sales at Jawoll increased by 8%, with
positive LFL over the period. The business benefited from the introduction of seasonal
lines from the B&M sourcing network. The new store trials are performing well and the
pace of expansion will step up with 10 new outlets next year as the new distribution
infrastructure comes on stream.
● Forecasts unchanged: The group remains comfortable with market expectations for
the FY. We forecast Q4 LFL of +1% and expect the UK EBIT margin to be broadly
flat during H2, with gross margins slightly higher due to mix benefits (non-food content
within larger new store openings) offset by a slight squeeze on SG&A ratios due to
capacity utilisation. Our numbers show FY group EBITDA growth of 17% despite a
modest currency headwind.
● Sell-off in shares overdone: We recognise the importance of the UK LFL trend as
a measure of the health of the format and longer-term viability of the expansion plan.
However, the 20% share price hit over the past quarter looks overdone to us in the
context of unchanged forecasts. We believe that the business should deliver 1-2% LFL
within normal industry trading conditions and note that B&M's conservative definition
deflates this reported number by 2-3%.

11:43 am
BE

Tactical upgrade.

BE

Morgan Stanley rather less keen, re valuation mostly.

BE

Outlook: We have spoken to the company this morning and, as the statement
makes clear, it is confident of meeting full-year market consensus profit
expectations.
Based on last night's closing price and existing consensus forecasts, B&M is
trading on 18.2x Cal 2016 earnings, 13.7x EBITDA, with a 2.2% dividend yield.
This compares with a UK General Retail Sector trading on 14.2x, 11.9x and
3.0% respectively.

11:44 am
undefined
BE

So, quick revisit of Wood Group ......

John Wood Group PLC (WG.:LSE): Last: 554.50, down 1.5 (-0.27%), High: 562.50, Low: 544.00, Volume: 689.25k
11:44 am
BE

The subject overnight of the world's most nuanced M&A story.

BE

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3wwQavbpn

BE

So to summarise what brought us to this point ....

11:45 am

BE

As in, no approach made (clearly) but wheels in motion for one to happen.

BE

11:46 am
BE

When we put that to a second group of people, those people got very nervous about the idea of anything being written that might stymie a process.

BE

And when we put all that to a third group of people, the message we were given was that it was all stale.

PM

hmm

11:46 am
BE

BE

Wood Group has certainly been pitched to SNC, but it was one pitch among many, the group of people #3 insisted.

BE

So .......

11:47 am
BE

The story written overnight included the views of all three groups of people.

BE

That felt the most honest approach.

BE

And in that it hasn't required any response from the companies, I guess there's nothing more to say.

11:47 am
PM

But we need to keep an eye here

BE

Yes. We do. Very much. As the story says, the new chap running SNC was the one who bought Kentz and didn't make a fist of it.

BE

Anyway.

11:49 am
BE

I can also note that Investec upgrades Wood this morning.

BE

To its credit, Wood looks to have maintained operating margins in 2015, helped by aggressive cost-cutting. However, we believe it is only a matter of time before it succumbs given rising industry pressures given renewed capex cuts and cost pressures. Its balance of opex/capex activities, strong balance sheet and growing dividend are certainly offsetting factors. That said, downside earnings risks now look largely discounted, in our view, and we upgrade to Hold.

BE

That's part of a sector note that favours Petrofac among the "defensive names".

11:49 am
BE

The oil majors still appear determined to maintain their dividends and they are using capex as the flex. This will influence the duration of the OFS downturn. We expect a further 13% fall in spending in 2016.

BE

Sector themes. Based on our continued cautious view, our preferred exposure is uncontroversial. We look for: 1) asset-light business models (more resilient during a downturn); 2) a preference for opex-, rather than capex-exposure (lower risk); 3) within capex, low exposure to upstream (more likely to be deferred); 4) low exposure to fixed-price contracts; 5) higher exposure to MENA region (more resilient spending); 6) a strong balance sheet.

BE

A projected sector ROE of around 10% is a full 2pps below our forecast six months ago and well below the 15-20% over the past decade. This decline is partly cyclical, but also partly structural, in our view. Lower ROE and a lower proportion of retained earnings argue for a lower sector multiple than historical levels, even at normalised (‘mid-cycle’) earnings. Consequently, we move our fair value for the sector from 11x to 10x normalised earnings.
Within the larger caps, we upgrade Petrofac (from Hold to Buy) on restructuring, MENA exposure and valuation. Amec Foster Wheeler (Hold) looks cheap, but needs to regain investor trust. We upgrade Wood Group (from Sell to Hold) on balance sheet strength, but remain nervous of margin weakness. Within the asset heavier E&C space, we prefer Technip (Hold) versus Saipem (Sell). At the smaller end of the scale, Cape remains at Buy, scoring heavily on the above criteria, with a discount valuation and superior yield. We like Lamprell (Buy) on its MENA exposure and believe it has been overly punished over worries about its 2017 backlog. Hunting (Hold) remains the most operationally leveraged name in our coverage, but faces a tough year ahead.

11:50 am
BE

Oh, and if you want a rather firmer story ..............

BE

WebMD scoop overnight, with James FK and Arash.

BE

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3wwQavbpn

11:50 am
BE

Give that some traffic, if you like. Ta.

ASOS PLC (ASC:LSE): Last: 3,101, down 79 (-2.48%), High: 3,170, Low: 2,971, Volume: 869.50k
PM

But this statement has really excited

11:52 am
PM

http://www.investe...1601140700078097L/

PM

ASOS has reported strong trading for the four months to end December, with total Retail sales growth of +22%, in line with consensus expectations. UK sales grew +25% and International +20%. Retail gross margin fell 40bps, as expected and FY guidance remains unchanged. ASOS is a conviction BUY. The company has now invested ahead of growth with distribution centres overseas. 56% of the Eurohub was unused at y/e but will come on stream as European sales grow, with a similar story in the US. Moving product closer to customers improves delivery times & customer acquisition. Operating leverage should drive EBIT margins from 4.0% in FY15 to 5.6% by FY18.

PM

That's Liberum

11:52 am
PM

Still bemuses me. Lauding international expansion -- in to markets taht are already covered by dozens of other online frock operators

PM

George Mensah at Shore also saying buy

PM

This represents performance in line with market expectations for the company; similarly sales in the UK were also in line as revenue increased 25%. Whilst our own expectations were ahead of consensus, we note there was only mild retail gross margin regression (c40bps), with planned price investments offset by a strong full price sell through. This is reflected in average basket value growth, while ASOS also saw an encouraging 18% increase in its customer base to 10.7 million. With its strong offering in both menswear and womenswear, we feel it is unsurprising the business achieved a record sales performance during the cyber weekend in late November 2015 and the consistency and increasing convenience of its proposition means strong trading likely continued in the run up to Christmas too. We feel its offering in mobile is particularly a key factor within this performance, with mobile representing 65% of traffic (up from 50% in P1 FY2015). We also note a triple digit increase in visits to the ASOS mobile app.

International sales increased 20% compared with the same period in FY2015, with double digit growth in both Europe (29% growth) and the U.S.(42% growth). The latter territory benefitted from currency tailwinds as the US dollar strengthened against the sterling towards the end of the period. Both territories were identified by management as a key focus. The Rest of World segment saw a 2% increase in sales during the period (13% in constant currency), a muted performance impacted by currency headwinds and lesser price and proposition investments compared with Europe and the U.S. segments.

11:53 am
BE

(@doeswalk: yes, but it needs a few more calls. At the moment I've nothing to add to what was written back in November.)

PM

Operationally the business is making progress with its infrastructure, and construction of the second EuroHub facility started in December 2015. We expect this to be operational at some point in CY2017.

Based on last night’s market close, ASOS trades on a FY2016 PER of 55.1x falling to 40.6x in FY2017F and a FY2016F EV/EBITDA of 22.4x falling to 17.1x the following year based on our forecasts. ASOS continues to make strong progress under new leadership, with this being said we do not anticipate any upgrades in the market and expect management guidance to remain where it is currently. Similarly, we are content with our forecasts for the current year as well as our bullish outlook for the company. BUY.

11:56 am
PM

PM

Rocket's is said to be losing two more senior executives according to a Reuters report. Both Franziska Leonhardt, head of its legal department, and Uwe Gleitz, senior vice president of corporate finance, are believed to be leaving for "personal reasons". Both were instrumental in the IPO process and it is hardly the best of timing if the #2 in corporate finance is leaving at a time the company is not only preparing FY results but also undertaking a process of higher disclosure in financials.

Last week Rocket backed Easy Taxi exited the Asian market, unable to compete with Tencent backed Didi Kuaidi and Uber. At its peak Easy Taxi covered 420 cities and 20 Asia countries. Easy Taxi is retreating back to Latin America, where it began. Easy Taxi is within the Latam Internet Group business, a subsidiary (Rocket own 65%) which has seen no change in LPV (total LPV of €270m) throughout 2015.

PM

Rocket Internet's LPV (as at November 30th, their own calculation) was €6.06bn which is a measly increase from €6.03bn at the end of September. Driving the increase is an increased valuation at FoodPanda which is strange given the fundamentals in the business has turned south and at Linio, a general merchandise business with an adjusted EBITDA margin of -84% and order growth of negative -18%. Linio is the "biggest online store in Latin America". A strange claim for a business with 9 month net revenues of €51. 6 million when, the last time we checked, larger well-established rival MercadoLibre reported 9month sales of US$470 million.

We remain vehement sellers of Rocket Internet.

11:57 am
PM

So head of legal and head of corp finance gone or going

BE

(@Via Con: you're a Blinkx holder and you read us? Well, I guess we should applaud your contrarian approach to this stuff.)

PM

One to watch taht, still

11:58 am

BE

Here's Shore.

BE

Better profitability is obviously good news however the company is still expected to be loss making at the EBITDA level of $10.8m this year (this is most likely slightly better now), but if it can continue to reduce costs against a rising market for the core services it provides it could become profitable next year. Blinkx’s high cost base and resulting lack of profitability is its burden and further programmatic operation can help reduce this further against the backdrop of a very healthy market for programmatic, especially in mobile and video formats. Measures to improve brand safety have been beneficial for it within its customer base and if it can continue to reduce costs, the shares have value considering it had $75.0 million in cash and marketable securities at the interim results to September 2015. It is expected to make a small EBITDA loss next year, but this could be improved with further headcount reduction driven by increasing programmatic operations. It currently trades on a one year forward EV/Sales multiple of 0.04x based on estimates available on Bloomberg.
